stem: The patient is exhibiting signs of possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Review the nurse's notes below and highlight all findings that support this suspicion. Only highlight the specific findings, not the surrounding text.

itemContext.sbar: Situation: John Smith, 68-year-old male, post-op day 3 following a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated. Background: History of COPD and hypertension. Procedure was uncomplicated. Assessment: At 06:00, vital signs were stable: BP 130/80, HR 88, RR 16 (ventilator settings), SpO2 95% on FiO2 40%. However, at 08:00, I noted a change in respiratory status. Recommendation: I recommend a stat chest x-ray and sputum culture to rule out VAP. Consider increasing the PEEP to improve oxygenation. Patient also received scheduled morphine at 07:00. The patient's oral care was completed at 07:30 using chlorhexidine. Suctioning was performed at 07:45, yielding thick, yellow secretions. Patient is on continuous enteral feeding at 60 mL/hr. The ventilator settings are: FiO2 0.4, PEEP 5 cm H2O, Tidal Volume 500 mL, Rate 14 breaths/min. Last dose of cefazolin was given at 05:00.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: WBC: 14,000/mm3 (High), Hemoglobin: 12.5 g/dL, Platelets: 250,000/mm3, Sputum Gram Stain: Gram-negative rods present. Sputum Culture pending.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
05:00: Cefazolin 1g IVPB
07:00: Morphine 2mg IV
Continuous: Enteral Feeding 60mL/hr

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
06:00: BP 130/80, HR 88, RR 16 (Ventilator), SpO2 95% FiO2 40%, Temp 37.2°C
08:00: BP 140/90, HR 98, RR 16 (Ventilator), SpO2 92% FiO2 40%, Temp 38.5°C

rationale.correct: Elevated WBC count, Temperature increase, Thick, yellow secretions, SpO2 decrease
rationale.incorrect: The other findings, such as stable vital signs at 06:00, morphine administration, chlorhexidine oral care, and cefazolin administration, are not directly indicative of VAP. These are standard aspects of post-operative care or medication administration.
clinicalPearls: VAP is a significant complication in mechanically ventilated patients, increasing morbidity and mortality.
Early identification of VAP through vigilant monitoring and assessment is crucial for timely intervention.
Strict adherence to infection control protocols, including hand hygiene and oral care, is essential in preventing VAP.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus on individual vital signs without considering the overall trend or may misinterpret routine care activities as indicative of infection.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Emphasize the importance of analyzing trends in vital signs and lab values, rather than focusing on isolated data points. Teach students to differentiate between routine care and signs of infection.

mnemonic.title: TRACHEA
mnemonic.expansion: Temperature elevated, Respiratory distress, Auscultation (abnormal breath sounds), Change in sputum, High WBC, Early identification, Action (obtain cultures).
